revised_title: Barometric Measurements and the Height of Mountains: A Case Study in Savoy
tldr: In this article, Sir George Shuckburgh discusses his experiments to determine the height of mountains using a barometer in Savoy. He examines and compares the methods of another scientist, Mr. De Luc, and provides a detailed account of his observations, measurements, and the instruments used. Shuckburgh's findings contribute to the understanding of the precision and accuracy of barometric measurements in determining the height of mountains.
